source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: In zirconium and Zircaloy, the development of the strong deformation texture is caused by the complicated interaction between slip and twinning.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The factor governing the texture formation is the material flow, which for tube reductions is determined not only by the reduction in cross-section, but in addition by the reductions in wall thickness and diameter, and more specifically by the relative ratio of wall to diameter reduction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: For metals or alloys with a below-normal c/a ratio (c/a < 1.633), as for example zirconium, titanium, and hafnium, the position of the basal poles is tilted by ±30 to 50 deg from the normal direction toward the transverse direction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: For metals or alloys with a below-normal c/a ratio (c/a < 1.633), as for example zirconium, titanium, and hafnium

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Experiments following the texture development in polycrystalline material, including also lower degrees of deformation, are described in Ref 16. The activated deformation systems had been followed in detail after various sequential rolling steps in the individual grains of a polycrystal with an almost random orientation.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: After each of six steps (from 0.5 percent up to a total deformation of over 60 percent) the operative slip and twinning systems were correlated with the respective lattice rotations

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The results show that in a coarse-grained polycrystal the criterion of compatibility by von Mises [17] is fulfilled; that is, in each individual grain at least five mutually independent deformation systems are activated.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of slip on the lattice rotation is shown in Fig. 1. As the slip traces show, threefold slip of the main slip system on prism planes in the a-direction does occur.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Simultaneously with slip, twinning is activated even at low degrees of deformation, for example, 0.5 percent (see Fig. 2).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Figure 3 demonstrates how the information for a specific grain orientation was gained. For this example, due to a compression component parallel to the c-axis, primary {1 122} twin systems have been activated.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: These processes can be followed up to 20 to 40 percent total deformation.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: for basal positions in the area 0 to 50 deg from the normal direction, irrespective of the azimuthal position of the basal pole, {1 122}-twinning becomes preferentially operative. Under a compressive strain component parallel to the c-axis, this twinning system rotates the basal pole by approximately 64 deg away from the center of the pole figure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: for orientations in the area 50 to 90 deg from the normal direction, again irrespective of the azimuthal position of the basal pole, {1012}-twinning becomes preferentially operative. Under a tensile strain component parallel to the c-axis, this twinning system rotates the basal pole by approximately 85 deg toward the center of the pole figure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: {1121}-twinning can be activated over the entire reference sphere. Under a tensile strain component parallel to the c-axis this twinning system rotates the basal pole by approximately 34 deg, preferentially toward the center of the pole figure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: For 20 to 40 percent total deformation the basal poles align further toward the final stable texture (0002) ±30 to 50 deg in the transverse direction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: For wire drawing: random distributed in the radial-tangential plane (fiber texture)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: For sheet rolling: Alignment in the normal direction, with a tendency to split toward the transverse direction by ±30 to 50 deg

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: For tube reducing: Alignment occurs in the radial-tangential plane. Depending on the reduction parameters, the alignment may occur preferentially in the radial direction, in the tangential direction, in intermediate positions, or also randomly distributed in the radial-tangential plane

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: For all cold-deformed semi-finished products, a [1010]-direction is parallel to the direction of deformation

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: The reduction of tubing is a complicated deformation process with a triaxial state of stress-strain condition which can vary according to different fabrication techniques

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: Tubing deformed by a high wall thickness and a low diameter reduction ( R _ { W } / R _ { D } > 1 , Fig. 6a) is mainly compressed in the radial direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: the resulting strain ellipse leads to a (0002)-figure with the basal poles preferentially parallel to the radial direction (within ± 3 0 to 50 deg tilted to the tangential direction)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: If the wall thickness reduction is more or less equal to the diameter reduction ( R _ { W } / R _ { D } ≃ 1 , Fig. ^ { 6 b } ), that is, the deforming compressive forces operate with equal strength in the radial and the tangential directions, then the strain ellipse converts into a circle

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: The result is a fiber texture with a random distribution of basal poles in the radial-tangential plane

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: Tubing deformed by a small wall thickness and a large diameter reduction ( R _ { W } / R _ { D } < 1 Fig. ${ \mathfrak { 6 } } c$ ) is mainly compressed in the tangential direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: in the (0002)-figure, the basal poles align preferentially in the tangential direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: FIG. 7—Textures in zircaloy tubing corresponding to the schematic cases of Fig. 6: ( a _ { 1 } / a _ { 2 } ) Basal poles preferentially parallel to the radial direction, as often observed in tubes after the final reduction step

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: (b) Basal poles randomly distributed in the radial-tangential plane, as often observed in tub after intermediate rductin steps

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: Basal poles preerentially parallelto the tanentali rection, as often observed in tubes after exirusion

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: The three types of texture discussed in Fig. 6 represent final stable positions; that is, further deformation with the same reduction parameters will not change the basal pole position

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: There may, however, be an increase in sharpness and intensity of the pole distribution

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: In the upper row a tube wall is reduced with a high wall thickness reduction. The diameter reduction is more or less constant over the wall and, in this example, is small compared with the wall thickness reduction.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: the degree of flow in the radial direction at the outer surface is large enough to shift the basal pole position strongly from its original ±45 deg tilt toward the center of the pole figure

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: At the inner surface, only a small shift of basal poles toward the center can be accomplished

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: In the middle row, the reduction in wall thickness and diameter is assumed to be such that the radial and tangential strains stay constant in all layers of the tube wall

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: No texture gradient is to be expected across the tube wall

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: the tangential compression strains were chosen to exceed the radial ones, so that a spread of basal poles toward the tangential direction results

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: In the lower case a tube is reduced so that the reduction in the outer diameter is high but the inside diameter does not change significantly

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: the basal poles are shifted more toward the radial direction at the inside of the tube wall than at the outside

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: Spread of basal pole maxima decreases from inner to outer diameter

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: Spread of basal pole maxima stays constant from inner to outer diameter

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: Spread of basal pole maxima increases from inner to outer diameter

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: the basal poles are preferentially parallel to the normal direction with a tendency to spread by ±30 to 50 deg toward the transverse direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: Neither fabrication method [tube reducing (rocking), mandrel drawing, planetary ball swaging, hammer swaging] nor a change in the deformation direction causes significantly different textures when the processes are carried out with corresponding reductions in wall thickness, diameter, and area

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: During the drawing process of wire, the material is compressed concentrically, which results in a diameter decrease and finally in an axial extension of the wire

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: In the plane normal to the axial direction the strain ellipse converts into a circle (Fig. 12)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: the basal poles become randomly distributed in the radialtangential plane

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: This fiber texture is identical to tubing, if it is deformed with $R _ {  } / R _ { D } \\simeq 1$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The basal pole figure does not change significantly during annealing

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: the basal poles concentrate more toward the normal or radial direction, respectively

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: the pole density is simultaneously somewhat increased or decreased

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: During recrystallization with increasing annealing temperature, the basal planes rotate continuously by $\\pm 3 0$ deg around their pole

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: instead of a [1010}- direction (cold deformation texture), a [1120]-direction becomes parallel to the rolling or axial direction, respectively

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: In tubing different features of annealing textures can develop, depending on the relative reductions in wall thickness and diameter, the degree of deformation, the temperature of deformation, and on the deformation method before annealing (extruding, rocking, drawing)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: a split of basal poles of $\\pm 3 0$ to 50 deg toward the transverse or tangential direction, respectively

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: For $R _ { W } / R _ { D } > 1$ the basal poles are oriented preferentially in the radial direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: for $R _ { W } / R _ { D } \\simeq 1$ the basal poles are randomly distributed in the radial-tangential plane

evidence_span: for $R _ { \\mathrm { \\Delta \\psi } } / R _ { D } < 1$ the basal poles are preferentially directed toward the tangential direction

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: a [1010]-direction will be parallel to the deformation direction in the cold-deformed condition

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Seven batches of Zircaloy-2 tubing with widely different textures were processed from tube shells of the same size, by different reduction routes, using pilger and 3-roll mills

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The quantitative relationship between the texture parameter and the newly proposed strain ratio parameter was established using empirical equations in the case of both as-rolled and full-annealed tubing

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The deformation texture of Zircaloy-2 tubing was dependent on the tool's curvature and was independent of the dimensions of the mother tubes

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The different slopes of texture gradients were observed between the tubing of higher strain ratio and that of lower strain ratio

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: the different types of the basal pole shift during annealing in the α temperature range were observed in the tested tubes

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Your tubing texture was ϕ_max⁰ = 20 to 40 deg

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: hydride platelets are known to precipitate with ±7 to 25 deg parallel to the basal plane

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: The texture of Zircaloy fuel cladding tube is known to be very important because of its influence on their physical and mechanical properties.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: The texture of Zircaloy tubing, on the other hand, is known to be very dependent on fabrication parameters such as strain ratio [7-9], tool's curvature [10] and heat treatment [11].
